list.text: Finding a database that collects all the daily and accumulative statistics of COVID19.
Design how the web page would visualize the data.
Pull and process the data to match the visualization.
Tide up the code and optimize it.

content.text: To visualize different sets of data, I needed a database that collects all the daily and accumulative statistics of COVID19 since the day one.
After some googling, I found 'covid-19-apis.postman.com', and in there, I could check and compare a number of different readily available APIs.
I ultimately chose 'NovelCOVID API' since it  was documented well and offered the data that I wanted: the numbers of the total cases, active, recovered, deaths and more.

body.text: As designing something to look beautiful is not one of my strong points, I went with the basic looks using the Material-UI. Still, I wanted to display the numbers tidily. So, I decided to use cards to display global accumulated data and group them, using react-countup wrapper, I added animation to numbers to make it a little bit more interesting.

For daily statistics, I figured that charts would be best to represent daily data in that the user can compare and see the trend. I could've built something on my own using plain JS and CSS, but I decided to see if someone has built something better, and I found recharts.js.

content.text: I first used fetching, but after some research, I realized that axios is easier to use and supports broader browser support. It didn't seem terribly hard to use fetch with some workarounds and a little bit more code, but I figured why wouldn't I just use axios instead.

The naming of each data field didn't exactly match how wanted to use them in the app, and some of the data were missing such as the recovery rate, fatality rate, and new numbers for each case. Thus, I needed to process the data before I hand it over to the components.

At first, I was fetching the data one after another with individual async/await calls, but I quickly realized that I could call the async calls concurrently using Promise.all since each async calls are independent to one another.

summary.text: As the novel COVID19 has impacted a countless number of people all around the world, I wanted to build something that shows how impactful it has been in statistics. COVID19 Tracker is a single page web page that shows the global and per-country statistics of COVID19 in appropriate forms.
